threads.com:
Welcome to /diy/, a place to:

Post and discuss /diy/ projects, ask questions regarding /diy/ topics and exchange ideas and techniques.

Please keep in mind:
- This is a SFW board. No fleshlights or other sex toys.
- No weapons. That goes to /k/ - Weapons. The workmanship and techniques involved in creating objects which could be used as weapons or the portion of a weapons project that involves them (e.g., forging steel for a blade, machining for gunsmithing, what epoxy can I use to fix my bow) may be discussed in /diy/, but discussing weapon-specific techniques/designs or the actual use of weapons is disallowed. Things such as fixed blade knives or axes are considered tools, things such as swords, guns or explosives are considered weapons.
- No drugs or drug paraphernalia (See Global Rule 1). If you want to discuss something that could involve such things (e.g., carving a tobacco pipe from wood) that's fine, but make sure it's /diy/ related and doesn't involve drugs or it will result in deletion/ban.

Helpful links:
https://sites.google.com/site/diyelmo/
http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/

Some friendly suggestions for posting:
- First ask Google, then ask /diy/. Your question will probably be better received if you do so.
- List available resources (tools, materials, budget, time, etc.)
- Try to use pictures and explain the goal, if possible
- Be patient, this is a slow board; your thread will be around for days.
- Share your results! /diy/ loves to see problems solved and projects completed!

All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2515119
>detailed miniatures
Resin is way better than FDM for this.

>and probably some form fitting pieces
What size/detail are you talking about? Do they need to be durable enough to be worn? FDM is better for larger and more durable parts, and the material is usually cheaper, but it takes more post-processing to produce a smooth surface ready for final painting.

>Also what do I actually need to do for resin?
Get an actual resin printer and some resin (of whatever varieties suit your uses). Spare resin vats so you aren't unloading and cleaning them with every resin switch. A fumetight place to store those resin vats. A workplace away from sunlight with good ventilation. Gallon-scale IPA and a suitable container for washing, or a dedicated washing station. A UV light source or dedicated curing station (if you get a station, get a UV flashlight too for curing spilled resin on paper towels so it doesn't offgas from the trash bin). Rubber gloves, paper towels, sharp putty knife for removing prints, at least one spare memory card.

>How much will I end up spending on resin and accessories comparatively?
Different resins formulated for different purposes cost different amounts. Around $15/liter for cheapo ones to $75 for high performance moulding resin that can be used for things like vulcanizing rubber products, to several times that for specialty things like ceramic or metal impregnated resin intended to produce sintered parts. Good structural resins for utilitarian purposes may be in the neighborhood of $40-50 per liter, while decent modeling resins may be around half that. IPA is somewhat expensive in the amounts used for cleaning, but it's not awful if purchased in bulk. UV lights can be pretty cheap, so you don't HAVE to spend much on accessories. However, there is a tradeoff between cost and hassle. Making do with very basic cleaning and curing supplies is notoriously bothersome, while something like a Prusa CW1 makes it a breeze. The CW1 is $750, however.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2515125
>>and probably some form fitting pieces
Addendum to this: FDM does have the option of silk filaments, which can do a decent impression of metal as-printed. So far as I know, there isn't a comparable option for resin. On the other hand, it's a lot easier to get clear resin prints than with FDM if you want transparency.

last_replies.com:
>>2515087
Yeah it's probably fine to just start with that. I'd be sure to read the datasheet though to ensure all the specs are acceptable, like quiescent current and efficiency at certain operating points. Also do the thermal calculation to see what temperature it will be running at, and how much PCB heat-sinking you'll want. Chances are the datasheet's layout example will be good enough, if you're at liberty to put a bunch of vias around the IC.

Also consider what will happen if the motor is still rotating when the power cuts out, where its voltage may go to.

The way I do it is to rub it on with a rag, I basically do it like a french polish, except poly instead of shellac. I know the poly doesnt melt into the previous layers like shellac does so I do my coats as soon as the first layer is dry to the touch but (hopefully) still chemically active enough to bond with the previous layer.

I can put on one layer every 15 minutes like this. If you spend a whole day going at it you can get like 60 coats in a day. It goes on super fucking thin like this so its doesnt end up looking like plastic. anyway that is how I avoid sanding when I use poly.

If Im doing something and I either dont have the time to get drunk and rub poly on shit all day I will brush it on and let "tip off" with the brush its a technique to help avoid bubbles, its really simple and you can figure it out in no time. Then I let it dry completely, at least over night. and then sand with 220 and do as many more as I want like this. The last layer can be sanded through the grits to whatever you want and then polished with auto products.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Something I've been doing for a while in my spare time is taking apart old LCD monitors and hanging them up in front of suitable light sources eg a light-coloured wall, or curtains when the sun is shining on them. This is an old 1280x1024 LCD screen powered by a raspberry pi 3 with an HDMI to DVI cable. This monitor was a good choice for this project because it takes a 12V input from an external power brick instead of using a mains voltage "jug cord" cable. I have taken apart monitors where the power supply was powered by mains voltage, but a cable runs from the power supply PCB to the "brain" PCB (which has the video input connectors on it) and only supplies it with 12V and 5V, and it seemed to work just fine with only the 5V supplied.

The Raspberry Pi has a generic DS18B20 temperature sensor which are a couple of bucks from aliexpress so I made it shit out a text based graph, that's on the left. The top graph shows a few weeks of temperature, the bottom shows 24 hours. The terminal just updates with "tail -f graph". On the rhs it's running a digital and an analogue version of xclock.

>How reliable those are, I mean, do false trippings happen?
Yes, false trips do happen with AFCI, usually with certain kinds of motors or other applications such as arc lamps and welders.

It's an example of using a one-size-fits-all solution that causes problems for some users. It also increases the construction cost of a new home by several hundred dollars, which provides only dubious safety benefits.
IDK if the cost of installing these AFCI everywhere across the country will wind up exceeding the cost of fires or damage that they are supposed to prevent.

last_replies.com:
>>2514834
You need
>speed control
>variable mini chuck
>set of thin ~3mm diamond grinding bits
>fiber reinforced cutoff discs
The thin diamond grinding bits can do anything, wood, glass, metals (with the right RPM), and don't gum up anywhere near as fast as the regular stones. Them being thin also helps with the surface speed. Obviously they're still slow at removing material, this is just meant for improving fits and removing maybe 0.5-1mm bumps, opening up bolt holes that just don't quite fit.
Fiber reinforced cutting disks can actually cut things, unlike the regular resin ones that shatter in 5 seconds. The battery powered tools usually don't like them since they don't have enough torque, but if you go easy it still sort of works.

Hello, have a relay 12.5v, drawing 400mA at the coils. also possibly damaging the control circuit with flyback.

What's a good diode?

I am reading that i need a "flyback" diode, which is a "schottky" diode - but digikey does not have this as a selection. Can find 'rectifier" diodes and "current limiting"

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Lesson Learned The Hard Way

If you install a high load current relay, such as the ones for car audio, you need to install a diode! AND there's a reason WHY automotive relays that come with the car look different!

they have the fucking diode built in!

What I learned from this:

studying schematics of the wiper system
testing the wiper system, determining the fault at the BCM - body control module.
found out there's a recall regarding the BCM. requires re-seating, dielectric grease on pins, re-torquing of the bolt.
THEN, you have to re-sync the car computer with the way the crankshaft is moving, using a laptop i had to build!
then believing the source of my problems in the first place may have also been the lack of a diode, as well the recall.

Can you fucking believe this life! You fix one thing then there's a new problem.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
and if you DON'T re-sync the car computer expect lower than usual pedal response, and bad fuel mileage costing around $8-$10 more per fill.

so you can see that this cheap little diode is vital for the installation of some electrically powered auxiliary equipment such as an office, sound system, electrical tool outlet, for your ride.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: you don't want to go messing with control modules as a relay trigger unless you have a diode in reverse bias on that relay coil.

how do various wood finishes look with age?

i'm refinishing furniture for an AK. as in, i'm sanding, staining, and finishing the wooden parts on a rifle.
tung oil seems like a really safe option, since it penetrates the wood. it wont stand up to wear like urethane will, but it's resistant to solvents like gun cleaning oils. the downside is that it has to be reapplied regularly. i don't really know what happens if you don't reapply it. does it just look like shit eventually?
this lead me to look into coatings used for wood floors. something like a hardwax oil is like a penetrating oil, but there's also a wax component which sits on the surface, and it's good enough that people use it for floors in their house.
i'm unsure how the wood would look if i neglected it. with shellac, for example, it cracks and flakes off and looks like shit.
how does a hardwax oil finish look when neglected compared to a tung oil or danish oil?
i have the feeling that it'll look scuffed up and dusty, because there is a thin coating of wax on top. it'd look like an old urethane coated floor.
whereas with something like a penetrating oil, the color might fade but maybe it wouldn't look like there's a scuffed up film on it, because there's no film on it.

It will actually stand up better to wear if you apply it right. Thin it with turpentine until it is thin enough to completely soak into the wood, the wood should look wet but not covered with anything. Let dry. Apply more coats until a film finish builds up. On hardwoods this generally will take about a week or two depending on how thinned it is which determines drying/buildup time. You can add some Japan Drier if you want to speed up the process some. Give it a fresh coat every year or just touch up any damage. The drying oils never stop getting harder and their bond with the wood/themselves is much better than that of poly.

If you want to go all out and are in no rush at all, get raw linseed oil, soak the stock in it for a week or two, hang it to dry for 6 months, possibly a year, however long it takes. Raw oils are very slow to dry but they penetrate in deeper than anything else.

If you are in a rush, CPES (clear penetrating epoxy sealer) is probable second best to a properly applied drying oil, especially if you want something other than the coated in plastic look.

>What's a reputable brand?
Rolair and Ingersoll Rand come to mind, but most DIYers would have better economy from a cheaper brand, and the reasonable options vary by location. I'm not familiar enough with AEG to comment. You can check reviews for that and other models to see if people are generally satisfied with their offerings, or if there are recurring issues.

>What's considered little or big?
~1-5 gallons is little for a portable compressor, and can typically be picked up with one hand and carried around. ~10-ish is medium, and often comes on wheels to cart around easily. 20-30 gallons is on the larger end of what is made to be moved around by hand but is small for a fixed shop unit. 60 gallons and 2-3 horsepower is medium for a shop compressor, and 80-100 gallons and 5hp is on the large end of consumer air compressors. An additional option is auxiliary air tanks to increase the system's stored air capacity. I have a semi-mobile shop compressor that can run a plasma cutter at 100% duty cycle, and some air tanks that allow reasonable run times on big blow guns and small grinders.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
So I have an old 12v car battery that has been sitting in the garden for at least 10 years. Voltage measures 0.1v. Smart charger refuses to charge it. It's dead Jim.

So I connect it to vintage charger the same as in the pic. Literally just a transformer and a diode outputting dirty DC. At first nothing happens, so I just leave it for a couple of hours. I come back and find the battery is taking 4 amps, not overheating or gassing at all.

I switch it to a modern smart charger which now recognizes it and happily completes the charge. Two days later it's still holding 12.5v and has enough juice for stick welding.

I don't get it. Everything online says this is impossible. Yet I've had consistent results doing this with many different "dead" lead acid batteries. Even after 10 years of sitting at 0.1v it still revived. Am I the fucking battery whisper or is my vintage charger magic?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2514414
a very long charge is called a maintenance charge, and should be done regularly on deep cycle batteries.

the problem with modern batteries is that in order to get maximum AH from them they use specially formulated plates that are very close together.

old batteries often had plates of pure lead and not as many of them so when they sulphated they were less likely to short and when desulphated there was space for the bits that often broke off to fall and not cause a short.

once a modern battery is sulphated it is near impossible to fully desulphate them or revive them (regardless of the voodoo you see on youtube) for any length of time.

I have had many a battery where the plates in one cell short (gets hot in one spot when charging) and that's it for that battery.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2514384
>is my vintage charger magic?
no. it's doing exactly what it was designed to do. smart chargers are meant for good batteries in good condition that are never over discharged. being "smart" just means that they won't output voltage if they don't sense a voltage over a certain amount (usually 10v for a 12v battery) then they shut off when the battery is charged which means they will never do a maintenance charge.

smart chargers are for joe average who wants to charge a battery and not think about it, old chargers are for people think and pay attention.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
After a quick google search the stochiometric ratio for LPG is 15.6-15.8:1.

So if you mix one unit of LPG with 15.6-15.8 units of Air you're getting the maximum of energy, or heat in this case, out of it.

If you have a pressure gauge on your bottle you can calculate the massflow of your gas and use that to adequately calculate the needed massflow of air you need for a full combustion. Going by the massflow you can then get your volumeflow (as that's how blowers/fans are usually specified) by dividing by the air density.

However as the anon above me pointed out that may be undersireable as your foundry might not withstand the temperature at complete combustion (about 2000°C or ~4000°F). You would have to cool the walls with a cold airflow or inject additional air into the combustion to burn leaner so the extra air cools it down.

Although a flow meter in your line would greatly simplyfy calculating all that.

Turbojet mechanic out. Also google is your friend nigger.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: In practice you're gonna find that theoretical stoichiometric ratios are not all that useful. As other anon said, there are all kinds of losses and inefficiencies that make theory a poor match for reality. Just make a setup that you can adjust easily and tweak it until it works good.

last_replies.com: Early in the previous thread I posted about making a custom edge bander for my chipboard chest-of-drawers-project. On the upside, after some fine-tuning and getting low viscosity EVA glue, I started seeing passable results. On the downside, the passable results still required manual re-gluing with an iron about 70% of the time, maybe down to 50% after I got the hang of the required speed and consistency of feeding. Still, it was a massive pain in the ass to do some 40 meters of edging this way. I also didn't have a very good setup for trimming edges with a router, did a lot of it manually with a chisel. All in all, it probably took like 10+ hours to do the edging, not including the time spent building the edge bander.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2514476
After suffering through all that and finishing the project, I went and bought a chinkshit horizontal edge bander. The vertical one I built might've been passable after some further improvements for small pieces, like the sides of drawers, but it was really hard to handle larger parts, like the top plate. It was also completely impossible to use it for banding thicker than 1mm, even 1mm was difficult. 0.5-0.7mm was alright.
This is what I then bought https://www.aliexpress.com/item/4000569137844.html and first tests went well. It's pretty fast, the bond it leaves is really strong as it applies glue on both the ABS strip and the wood, and thanks to all the big rollers you can squeeze the edge on hard, even 2mm strips stuck just fine. Will see how it holds up next time I actually have a larger amount of edges to glue. Also I will definitely build a swiveling router mount for cutting the banding, I've had it with chisels.
The steel frame was an extra layer of complication, if I had to build the same thing again, I'd either go with thinner material or just use chipboard for the whole structure. Also it's really fucking heavy.

OP, I find a toothbrush and dawn will usually do the job.
Then I fill two teacups with white vinegar. Place one right side up in the top basket and one in the bottom basket.

threads.com: So I decided to check all the receps in my house, and one of them had a hot/neutral reversed according to my tester. The top outlet on the recep was hooked up to a switch. Took off the decorative plate and sure enough I had a phase on the top neutral terminal and a phase plus neutral wire on the bottom neutral terminal. Looked on the other side and had a neutral wire on the top phase terminal. Wtf??? I rewired it correctly with a new recep and tested it. For shits and giggles I flipped the light switch on and it ended up tripping my breaker. Said fuck it and disconnected the switch and capped and taped off the wires. Did I do something wrong here? I'm not a licensed electrician.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2513715
You're only highlighting your own ignorance. Under certain fault conditions, it is less safe to have the neutral and phase reversed in a receptacle.

Under normal operation where everything is working correctly, there is no operational difference. It is only under certain fault conditions where the difference is meaningful.

Consider something like a space heater with a nichrome coil inside, and a switch which turns the device on and off. If phase and neutral are reversed, then the switch will now be located on the "low" side of the circuit, and even while the device is switched off the entire coil will be at 120v. This is less safe than the way that it is intended to operate.

Consider a case where the device is fused only on the "high" side of the circuit and it develops a ground fault which should be large enough to blow the fuse but not large enough to trip the circuit breaker for this circuit. If the polarity is reversed, the entire case could be electrically live or a fire could start where this problem would resolve itself with a correct polarity receptacle.

Why do you think that there is a code requirement about this if it "does not fucking matter"? Why do you think that simple circuit testers bother to detect a reverse polarity connection? Why do you think receptacles are even polarized at all with different sized slots?
Do you think they just do all of that for fun? No, retard---- there are reasons for these decisions that go beyond your understanding.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2512241
>even the *shittiest* machines can hold ~.0001

That's about the limit of what you can do with a Hardinge super precision lathe in a climate controlled room. It's one thing to mic a shaft or a bore to tenths but another to actually have that precision in form and size. I'd bet that the majority of used lathes in standard shops struggle to even hold that kind of roundness. And no, you can't measure your spindle with a tenths indicator on a Noga arm like so many people try to do. As soon as you put it on a sturdy holder and use a lever gauge or at least a Millimess you will see how shitty your spindle is and there's lots of roller noise and other shit going on.

>>2513610
>the bored cylinders on a fucking ferrari are more loosely toleranced than a slip fit for a bearing

They most certainly are. New run of the mill engines are pretty shit actually (at least cylinder bores) and it's totally fine. Kind of the same concept for different reasons. You COULD mic them to microns but most shops will use standard 0.01mm bore gauges because it's all you need. As soon as you put it together, mount the engine and heat it up a few degrees everything moves to shit anyway. A torque plate will easily squish a bore a few thou in some engines.

threads.com: I work as an office wagie in a manufacturing environment, and I often work with engineers and our maintenance crew. I'm always impressed by maintenance's ability to keep absolute garbage machines going. I'm interested in what they do, and I'd like to expose myself to the skills they have. If I liked the style of work, I'd consider trying to become an apprentice. How could I expose myself to millwright-related skills that would make me more prepared to be an apprentice?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2511062
Take a machining course or a mechatronics course to begin with. Welding helps greatly. The reason for formal training is to speed up your early learning and expose you to theory of operation.

Many machinists become millwrights because the money is better. Talk to actual millwrights in your country to see what specific quals they want in a noob. There is no substitute for communication.

If serious ask if you can be a helper on night shift then stay late to learn. That makes you very impressive to any sane employer. I've done that several times to learn useful skills and it pays off.

All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2513782
How badly do you need those settings? Is this your first machine? You may be able to do without all 4.

You can get aftermarket needle positioners (if you need)
You can use a knee lift for the presser foot (if you need)
You don't need the auto lock stitch, for most applications manual is preferred
The auto pressed foot lift is cool, now I have it I love it but it can be done without and there may be a way to custom retrofit it. Reverse engineer from the solenoid or control mechanism, and wire a power source in thats controlled by the petal being pressed "up". If this doesn't make sense, of yours not electrically inclined, skip it.

Not sure where you're located but in the US you could sell this machine and buy something similar and working, for as much as it'd cost to get this working. Would skip a lot of hassle in conversion. But aye, what you said is true - a servo motor would get you going easily. The Consew one is cheap and ready to go with your pedal. And your handwheel can be retrofit for the needle positioner, and you may have to find a knee lift for that model.

Depends on location, cash to spend, and end sewing goals. Happy to keep sharing thoughts. I'm no sewing expert, they seem to be hard to find so I'm sharing what I know. Keep after it my man, these machines are very capable no matter the features, and making your own stuff is very fulfilling and frankly useful.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I've done foam board in my basement, with seams taped & a small gap top & bottom for spray foam to create a continuous barrier. That worked fine for eliminating condensation & blocking efflorescence, but I also put drain matt outside so not sure how well it would do if there was heavy water pressure from the outside.

Above that I framed it in with 2x2, pressure treated against the floor, and filled the space between studs with additional 1.5" foam board, then drywall 1/2" off the floor & no trim b/c basements flood.

I've seen the same thing done with an additional vapor barrier directly under the drywall, so I suppose if you really do have a big temp/moisture gradient, you might do that just to be safe.

threads.com: I always assumed that a tiny voltage would have trouble moving through a huge wire. That's why we use small wires for low voltage, right? Yet science tells me that in fact smaller wires have higher resistance so the voltage would actually travel though bigger wire better. Is this true? Would 1v travel better though a huge thick mains voltage cable than a small speaker wire??

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2507878
Water flows through a pipe voltage mostly moves on the outside of a wire. How are they same?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2507876
People are oversimplifying the answering
If you try to put a tiny current through a big wire, it will actually be met with way more resistance than a small wire as the current lacks direction so it can wander around the oversized highway instead of going straight through

Now, this is comparing recommended wire size and wayyy too big wire
If you're not sure what size ones, always go one step up and then use smaller fuses as a wire that's a size too small will have more resistance than a wire that's 2 or 3 sizes too big

When you get beyond those 2 or 3 sizes, though, you start to gain resistance against the current

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2508726
>>2510784
>>2509145
Jesus christ. for the purposes of any real conversation DC current flows through the entire cross-section of the conductor. We can be autistic about Maxwell equations all day long about how a conductor cannot have electric field and whatnot, but to go back to the hydraulic analogy that's practically the same thing as arguing that water doesn't flow in a pipe, the pipe just sets the boundaries.

Now, if you were to have a long large diameter wire and a short small diameter wire so that they have equal resistance, and applied the same voltage to them, the larger wire would in fact have the electrons moving slower, but there's more of them so the overall current is the same. In semiconductors (possibly all materials, only really relevant in semiconductors afaik), you will actually run into the limit of the electron drift velocity where increasing voltage does not increase current because the electrons cannot move any faster due to interacting with other shit in the atomic structure

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2507876
The simplest explanation is that small wires can't carry a lot of current, so if you want more energy, you raise the voltage or you increase the wire size. Welder cable is an example: it's low voltage, high amperage.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2510784
>voltage mostly moves on the outside of a wire.
In most cases not. It's called skin effect and depends on frequency. At 50 Hz the skin depth of copper wire is 9,22 mm which means that the wire needs to be over 9,22*2 = 18,44 mm in diameter for skin effect to happen.

18,44 mm diameter is equal to 270 mm2 cross section. 270 mm2 copper wire is rated about 500A which is a HUGE current

I bought this with a bunch of extra mixing spouts. The original railing was fixed with pretty large expansion bolts, but the stuff was to porous and worked loose any way.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505878
Chisel the whole area out
Get some L shaped anchor bolts
Put them in the hole and align them as needed(you may have to use small nails and wire to hold them in place, or Blu tac/bubble gum)
Refill hole with hydraulic cement(may need to make a cast to catch the concrete or rotate house on it's side).
Wait appropriate amount of time then reattach railing.
Wa la, and make sure you chisel the hole so the hydraulic cement has something. To cling onto.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505878
Measure the holes exactly
Buy a wood dowel that's the same exact diameter
Cut 2 sections to slide in that are about flush with the outside
Put the screws back in

This will only work if it's concrete, cement filled block or solid masonry but it's 100% effective and how they have done it for centuries

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2512030

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Buy some anchoring adhesive, get some threaded rod that fits the full depth, permanently glue that shit in there
They are expensive tubes but it's what pros use for rebar in construction, it's solid af in 5 minutes
Then slide the railing onto your now solid rod, attach with nuts/washers

Don't use plastic or other expansion fit, you'll just crack the concrete

Or you can find some steel to put on the wall to spread the load, people are always throwing out scrap
Hit around it with a hammer/chisel to make sure it's still solid

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2511803
>What happens if instead of conecting an air compressor to a pneumatic tool you conect a boiler
Residential steam boilers (for home heating) operate at less than 2psi. Even commercial steam boilers are under 15psi. You'd need a locomotive style boiler to get up to pressures that would be usable.
Even if you somehow managed to connect to a usable steam source you wouldn't be using your tool for long. The tool would get too hot to hold, the moisture would rust and corrode the guts, and the heat would melt the seals in the tool. I can only hope you're still holding it when the seals fail and the tool explodes.
Add to that the inefficiency of steam as a power source and the extreme cost of firing your boiler to the required temp and pressure.

tl;dr no you fucking mong

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I may have misunderstood but... Do online paper wallets exist??
If so, how do I create an OFFLINE paper wallet??

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
"online" and "offline" in this sense are really referring to the tool you use to document the private key for the public address.
Since most of these tools are online / web-based tools, the best practice is to save the tool/webpage locally, then disconnect from the internet, then use the tool to generate the key, then print the information.
If you're online when you do that, there's a chance that someone is observing you. If you're offline, the chance is reduced (unless you have some kind of keylogging malware on your computer).
